meanings.def: to take somebody/something in your hand suddenly and using force
examples: seize something from somebody She tried to seize the gun from him.
seize somebody/something He seized her by the arm.
She seized hold of my hand.
He seized the book from her hand.
The wrestlers try to seize hold of each other.

meanings.def: to take control of a place or situation, often suddenly and violently
examples: They seized the airport in a surprise attack.
The army has seized control of the country.
He seized power in a military coup.
The men were seized as they left the building.
Terrorists have seized five hostages.
He was immediately seized and thrown into prison.
A Briton has been seized by border guards and jailed for eight years.

meanings.def: to take illegal or stolen goods away from somebody
examples: A large quantity of drugs was seized during the raid.
We have the legal right to seize his property.

meanings.def: to be quick to make use of a chance, an opportunity, etc.
examples: The party seized the initiative with both hands (= quickly and with enthusiasm).
She promptly seized the opportunity his absence gave her.
The pirate was a renowned terror of the eastern seas.
It's a secret—make sure nobody sees!
She was eager to seize any opportunity that was offered.

meanings.def: to affect somebody suddenly and deeply
examples: Panic seized her.
He was seized by curiosity.

meanings.def: if a machine seizes, it no longer works because the parts are stuck and cannot move
if a part of your body seizes, you are unable to move it easily and it is often painful

related: take, claim, seize, etc. the moral high ground
